awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mantle to Crust Fluid Transfer in an Active Flat-slab Subduction Zone - Insights from Peruvian Thermal Spring Geochemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
Fluids play a prominent role in tectonic processes associated with plate tectonic subduction zones including mountain building, volcanic activity, fluid-fault interaction, and earthquakes. Most of what is known about fluid sources and flow pathways is from geochemical characterization of hot springs and fumaroles near active volcanoes located along subduction zone arcs (e.g., the Pacific Ring of Fire). In contrast, the source and composition of fluids along subduction zones segments that lack active volcanism is not well known. This project investigates the source and chemistry of fluids in this type of setting using an innovative set of geochemical techniques applied to hot springs in the Peruvian Andes. This part of the Andes is targeted because it is the best example on Earth today of 'flat-slab' subduction, that manifests as a prominent gap in volcanic activity along an arc. Research on fluids in this geological setting is important for the fundamental understanding of their role in this stage of the subduction cycle, and this work is transportable to other ancient and modern subduction zones worldwide. Springs can contain high concentrations of metals, and this research will identify spring systems that pose potential water quality issues for the Peruvian public. Beyond these scientific and societal impacts, the project is contributing to training of graduate and undergraduate students and workforce development in a STEM discipline. It is facilitating scientific collaboration between U.S. and Peruvian scientists, and is providing training opportunities for Peruvian students in field and analytical methods. The project will also support a workshop on water quality and geothermal issues in the western U.S. 

The primary research goal is to map the distribution of mantle- and slab-derived volatiles in the crust above a flat-slab subduction setting using the isotope geochemistry of thermal springs in Peru. This proposal builds on the prior results that identified up to 25 percent of mantle-derived helium in Cordillera Blanca hot springs with a geochemical sampling transect from the Cordillera Blanca (~9° South), southward including the Cordillera Huayhuash, a proposed 'slab-tear', the Nazca ridge, and the transition to steep subduction beneath the Altiplano plateau (~15° South). These data test the primary hypothesis that mantle helium in fluids above the Peruvian flat slab segment are geochemical manifestations of slab foundering north of the Nazca Ridge and ongoing slab dehydration and fluid transfer to the overriding lithosphere. A secondary goal targets the role of fault/shear zones in transferring fluids to the surface by comparing spring geochemistry and the paleofluid geochemistry preserved in fault rocks in the Cordillera Blanca versus the Cordillera Huayhuash. Multiple analytical tools will be used to address these objectives, including thermal spring water and gas chemistry, helium isotope ratios (3Helium/4Helium), 129Iodine, stable isotope analysis of fluids (carbon, nitrogen, chlorine, oxygen, and hydrogen) and fault rocks (hydrogen isotope ratios of micas), and fluid inclusion analysis of fault rocks. This project addresses the data gap on the nature of fluids in a flat-slab subduction setting, potentially identifying segments of the Peruvian trench that have subducted sediments, and providing a surface geochemical test for a proposed slab tear north of the Nazca ridge identified by geophysical investigations. Outcomes of this project may also serve as a modern analog for the role of fluids in ancient flat-slab subduction systems such as the Farallon slab under western North America.

por.por_cntn:
Fault-fluid interactions play a key role in determining the strength and longevity of large-scale geological structures. Interactions between surface-derived, meteoric waters and plastically-deforming fault zones have long been identified in extensional settings. These fossil fault-channelized hydrothermal systems are often correlated mineralization of ore deposits, including phases that are key to the green energy transition. While deep (>3-5 km) circulation of meteoric fluids into the crystal-plastic regime of detachment faults is almost ubiquitous, the timescales required to develop meteoric-hydrothermal circulation cells and their relationship to the hydrologic cycle during faulting has been tenuous. Much of our understanding of surface to mid-crust fluid pathways has been inferred from extinct shear zones with complex, polydeformational histories that leave ambiguity about fluid source and have limited ability to decipher temporal relationships between fluid sources, durations of hydrothermal circulation, and plastic deformation. This collaborative research project between the University of Tennessee and Utah State University investigated the source and timing of fluids infiltrating a crustal-scale normal fault during deformation. Our work targeted the Cordillera Blanca subrange of the Peruvian Andes because this locality is home to the only known example of an active, trench-parallel, brittle to ductile detachment fault coincident with ongoing regional contraction. This setting allows study of a recently exhumed shear zone that is still evolving in the context it originated from. The region is also host to many modern fault-channelized hydrothermal springs allowing for contrasts to be drawn between historic and modern hydrothermal systems.

For this project, we analyzed stable isotopes of hydrogen (δ2H) in muscovite and biotite from 48 samples across 9 strike-perpendicular transects through the entirety of the continuously exposed mylonitic shear zone in the footwall of the detachment. Granitic rocks are typically enriched in 2H relative to 1H, resulting in δ2H values of -60 to -30‰ in muscovite and biotite, whereas micas that have been deformed and recrystallized in the presence of meteoric waters are depleted in 2H relative to 1H. Resulting δ2H values vary based on the elevation and latitude of the surface-derived water sources present during infiltration, but typically present with δ2H values below -100‰. The clear distinction between magmatic and meteoric δ2H values, coupled with limited hydrogen in crustal reservoirs, makes δ2H values an ideal indicator of fluid source during deformation. Additionally, correlation of δ2H values of meteoric waters with elevation allows reconstruction of paleoelevation during the timeframe that the structure was active.

Our measured δ2H values range from -46‰ to -142‰, correlating with equilibrium water δ2H values of -22 to -112‰. Our findings indicate that the footwall shear zone is variably equilibrated with meteoric fluids derived from elevations ≥3400 +500/-700m, but potentially as high as 4100m. While evidence for meteoric-hydrothermal circulation is commonplace in mylonitic shear zones, the origin of fluids has been debated. Contrasting models suggest low δ2H values are derived from mechanisms other than downward migration of surface fluids. Our findings indisputably indicate equilibration of shear zone micas with meteoric fluids derived from high elevations in the modern Andes. Similarly, the presence of mixed fluid sources within single transects through the shear zone argues for a time or thermal dependence on the infiltration of water to mid-crustal depths.

We also collected 40Ar/39Ar ages from muscovite, biotite, and feldspar from 18 samples across the same 9 shear zone transects and 4 samples of undeformed footwall leucogranodiorite. Closure temperatures for the 40Ar/39Ar system in muscovite and biotite align with the range of deformation temperatures during quartz plasticity within the shear zone (~425–280°C), allowing interpretation of the timing of footwall shear zone formation. Meanwhile, feldspar multi-diffusion domain (MDD) models bridge the gap between ~280–60°C, preserved in existing low temperature thermochronometers. Ages from mylonitic samples correlate with increasing elevation and along-strike latitude. Contrasting this, mica ages from undeformed footwall rocks are youngest in the central portion of the range, but feldspar MDD models mimic the trends identified in mylonitic rocks. The now-exhumed shear zone was active between 5.31–3.75 Ma, with intersample mineral pairs recording cooling from ~425–280°C in 150–450 k.y. Feldspar MDD models mimic the cooling behavior of mica pairs from 400–280°C, preserving a pulse of rapid exhumation during detachment initiation before a decrease in cooling prior to ~3 Ma, when exhumation increased again.

Our research provides important constraints on the rates of large-scale fault initiation, fluid infiltration into the deep subsurface, and incipient shear zone development. Our findings provide important context into the development of high topography in the Andes and processes generating meteoric water signatures in detachment faults. This study has important implications for understanding fault-bound geothermal resources and may provide insight into ore-generating processes. Beyond these scientific and societal impacts, this project fostered a scientific collaboration between U.S. and Peruvian geoscientists and students. The project also supported the education and training of four graduate students and supported the research experiences of four undergraduate students.
